title: Thursday, 8th November 2018
bodyHTML:
11:05 am
BE11:05am

Sigh.

VV75 morning
VV75 bad day?
Soundbuy Morning..........
BE11:06am

Right, anyway, hello. Good morning. Welcome to Markets Live, FT Alphaville's hour of whatever this is I don't entirely know myself to be honest.

Amatuerinvestor morning
erlkin you'd think be now you'd have defined your role
Soundbuy There's a competition right there.......
BE11:07am

We start .... I dunno, here?

11:07 am
BE11:07am

https://www.ft.com...-8e70-5e22a430c1ad

Grouchmonkey Hola
Staffie Morning.. any news floating around EMG? tanked early in the week and continuing to slide..
Fox Big deal announced between Vectura and Hikma this morning targeting GSK's Ellipta inhaler range.
BE11:07am

BE11:08am

Or possibly here.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

https://twitter.com/camanpour/status/1057336868046430208

BE11:09am

Or we could concentrate on stuff that's within our remit, which is stocks going up and down.

undefined
11:09 am
BE11:09am

.... and inevitably, Vectura's among them.

Vectura Group PLC (VEC:LSE): Last: 79.60, up 8.2 (+11.48%), High: 80.35, Low: 75.75, Volume: 3.44m
BE11:10am

You'll remember that every Bandit10 and his dog of a portfolio got into Vectura last year on the idea that it was for sale.

TonaldDrump Tesla didn't go for James Murdoch then....? Called it.
erlkin i think oil is interesting....crude has been getting hammered yet several etf's are bucking the trend ie gush
Fox Was it the Daily Telegraph who touted a possible 175p/share GSK buyout of Vectura? Then there was the Sosei denial....
11:11 am
BE11:11am

The stock then soared from 120p-ish to about half that, albeit with the occasional pop back towards a quid as someone took it upon themselves to report the dead bid rumour.

BE11:12am

Today, we get actual news.

BE11:12am

Of sorts.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Vectura signs an expanded agreement with Hikma, an existing customer/partner to develop generic versions of GSK’s Ellipta portfolio.

Imperial Goldsmith Shire/ Takeda? The 1%er revolt seems to be getting a lot of coverage...
BE11:14am

Which it clearly great, as Ellipta is expected to sell absolutely shedloads.

BE11:14am

Panmure says net US sales of over $4bn by 2024

11:14 am
BE11:14am

And is the fastest growing bit of GSK.

BE11:14am

Problem is, nothing's going to happen for a really long time.

Fox What sort of % of profits would Vectura be expected to receive?
BE11:15am

You're looking at a decade before generic Ellipta arrives.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

So I can give you the detail on paydowns -- $15m upfront and mid-teens royalties on sales, plus a milestone payment of up to $75m due prior to launch .....

BE11:16am

But predicting whether that cash will actually pay out in any useful form is hoverboards and jetpacks territory.

BE11:17am

... "up to $100m of further sales based milestones on cumulative sales up to $5bn," says Panmure. Sure, sure.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Here's Citi.

Blank canvas any broker notes on Tate interim results?
VV75 Remind us in 9,5 years
BE11:19am

We expected an announcement on the “Open-Inhale-Close” portfolio
[generics for GSK’s Ellipta devices] before year-end, as guided at the interim results
in September; Hikma is a logical partner given the existing partnership with generic
Advair, VR506 [Flovent] and VR730 (Serevent).

BE11:19am

With combined GSK Ellipta
estimated US sales in 2027 of £2.4bn and potential royalty rate of
mid-teen, the opportunity for Ellipta generics is sizeable for Vectura, albeit a long
way off. The upfront payment of $15m will obviously benefit near-term cash flows.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Aside from Arnuity, composition of matter patent expiries in the US are mainly in the
late 2020s, which gives the HIK/VEC plenty of time to file ANDAs
with hopefully incorporated lessons learned from the protracted generic Advair
experience [CRL requiring an additional clinical endpoint study which should be
completed in 2019]. We expect that the market may not yet assign much value to
this project given the long time horizon.

BE11:19am

And Numis.

BE11:19am

We see Vectura's generic Ellipta platform deal with Hikma as a strong endorsement
of its IP - particularly its OIC (Open-Inhale-Close) inhaler device - and development
capabilities. Hikma, as the existing partner for VR315 (generic Advair), is the ideal
partner and we see its signing of the deal today providing a signal of its confidence
in VR315 also, in advance of a likely re-filing of this product in 2019 and potential
US launch in 2020. Deal terms are broadly consistent with our longer term forecasts
and valuation, which sees c.50p in value for the generics portfolio, with little of this
currently priced in, in our view. We upgrade for the second time in two months, with
our FY2018 Adj. EBITDA rising c.13% to £32m. Buy.

11:19 am
BE11:20am

Should briefly mention Hikma numbers as well.

BE11:21am

They've upgraded guidance thanks largely to its predatory pricing of hydromorphone.

GGekko Anything on Halfords?
BE11:21am

Having jumped on Pfizer's production problems.

Amatuerinvestor Tesla's board has got a new chairman
11:23 am
BE11:23am

Tends to be that Hikma's gouge strategy only gets priced at one turn, but the upgrades seem to be pretty regular now.

BE11:23am

Caz with the figures.

BE11:23am

After the guidance upgrade
with the H1’18 results, Hikma upgraded previously communicated guidance in the Injectables and generics divisions. Generics revenue is now expected to be $675-700m (prev. $600-650m), with low teens core operating margin (prev. mid-high single digit). Injectables guidance was upgraded to revenue of $825-850m, “39-40%” core operating margin (prev. $775-825m and mid to high 30s Core op margin). Branded revenue growth of “mid-single digits at constant FX” was reiterated. At both a group level, these guidance upgrades imply c.12% upgrades to consensus Core Operating profit and 10-11% upgrades to consensus Core EPS.

11:23 am
BE11:24am

Bottom-line: With the new guidance, current company collated consensus expectations for FY18 Core EPS could require upgrades of c.10-11% following these results and so we expect the stock to outperform today. Even with strong performance YTD (+62% vs. EU Healthcare [SXDP] +2%), we believe that the stock could outperform by more than 5% today reflecting these upgrades to consensus.

undefined
BE11:25am

Tate and Halfords we'll get to.

Waterloo Remarkable Trump press event. His comment on his tax returns beggars belief
11:26 am
BE11:26am

Shire, we probably won't. Rebel shareholders are always a good story but there's no real reason to think anything will happen here.

BE11:27am

As for Tesla ......

Fox Buying out one or both of Vectura/Hikma could save GSK a lot of hassle one would think? Combined market cap of £5Bn vs GSK $75Bn.
Grouchmonkey Lots of results this morning, none of which seem very interesting. Mildly interested in Inmarsat but no position in that any more....
BE11:27am

Robyn Denholm to be chair.

Waterloo 'Too complicated' for people to understand and that it would be 'war' if the Dems went after them. Admitted that ongoing 'audit' didn't prevent them being released just he won't
Flaneur That Mazzucato tweet is something else..... https://twitter.com/MazzucatoM/status/1060448125926735874
11:28 am
BE11:28am

(@Fox: show me a successful big pharma bid for a generic.)

nightingale20201 not convinced she is the best candidate out there....seems to me, jobs for the boys....could understand why EM consent to this appointment but that is hardly what textbook governance hopes for
BE11:29am

Internal appointment and, let's be honest, not a terribly interesting one.

erlkin he's prolly broke....who cares anyway... at least we don't have royals...we just have wannabe royals....his family will enrich themselves and fade away.....the american way
BE11:31am

Just searching the archive for any previous mention of her. The best I can find is as a statement cosignatory to the desperate bit of reverse engineering on the "funding confirmed" tweet.

11:31 am
BE11:32am

"Last week, Elon opened a discussion with the board about taking the company
private. This included discussion as to how being private could better serve Tesla’s long-term interests, and also addressed the funding for this to occur. The board has
met several times over the last week and is taking the appropriate next steps to
evaluate this."

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Royals have better values than most, if not all, US elite.
BE11:32am

That one. Which suggests she probably won't be too much trouble to Elon in the future.

Flaneur Is 'internal appointment' journo code for 'keeping a lid on things'?
BE11:33am

Anyway, the one thing I can throw into the mix here is that Tesla might be joining the SPX.

cracklenpop Sainsbury's?
11:33 am
BE11:33am

Next year. At least according to Macquarie.

BE11:33am

Based on our analysis, TSLA fulfils all requirements except one: sum of the last 4
quarters GAAP earnings has to be positive. We expect eligibility post-2Q19.

A. M. 'opened a discussion with the board' was a bit of a misstatement, surely. Unless a note wrapped around a rock thrown through the window counts.
Blackbag99 Is it a slow day? Is the window dressing at Tesla really that important
BE11:34am

Does it matter? Not really, though tracker funds vs shorts is always interesting.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Inclusion appears to have an impact on share price. We examined the 12
stocks added to the S&P 500 in the last 6 months. While performance was uneven
across the group, those not previously in the S&P 400 prior to inclusion in the S&P
500 saw an average share price increase of 6.9% (versus S&P 500 up 0.2% on
average) on the day of announcement. We note that TSLA is not in the S&P 1500.

A. M. but that's old hat.
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Tesla - the insignificant little terrier that keeps on barking.
VV75 @Blackbag I didn't read your company suggestion
BE11:35am

While TSLA still has to prove it can sustain profitability, we believe the company
will achieve this last eligibility requirement driven by steady demand for Model
S & X, increasing production to meet Model 3 demand, and potential for
meaningful ZEV credit revenue.

undefined
11:35 am
BE11:35am

(@Blackbag99: other stock commentary services are available if this one doesn't suit your requirements, whatever they might be.)

BE11:36am

Tate & Lyle? Sure.

Tate & Lyle PLC (TATE:LSE): Last: 688.80, up 2.6 (+0.38%), High: 710.40, Low: 687.00, Volume: 685.00k
Pharma Second request for Sainsbury's. Always nice when results are reported in MSM as variously "40% drop" and "20% rise".
11:36 am
BE11:36am

H1 results are a small beat.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Tesla is a good story and Elon is good at Jackanory.
BE11:37am

Guidance unchanged.

Blackbag99 @BE there are indeed!
TonaldDrump HAHA!
urgeview Autotrader, if possble.TIA.
BE11:38am

The year-end corn milling price settlements are likely to be what defines share price direction over the next couple of months though.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

And in that context: meh. Here's Martin Deboo at Jefferies.

BE11:39am

H1 has come in 3% ahead of our numbers and FY guidance is unchanged.
The beat to JEFe was principally on the central cost line and Primary Products
benefited from a £4m insurance settlement. But let's not be churlish here, in the
context of a still-undemanding valuation and a rebuilding reputation. Volume
momentum in Solutions is proving to be sustained and TATE is doing a better job
of managing industry headwinds than INGR. A positive statement in the round.

Soundbuy There's an intern polishing the zapper as we speak..............
BE11:39am

And Citi.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

TATE's H1 results were a small beat. Adjusted EPS of 27.9p was
+1.2% ahead of our forecast, helped by a better organic sales growth of +2% (Citi
+1%) and a slightly better EBIT margin of 12.0% (Citi 11.9%). Underlying sales
growth and margin delivery in the key F&B Solutions were better than expected,
while profit in the commoditized businesses was stable yoy and in-line with our
estimates. Most importantly, the shape of earnings delivery in H1 was in-line with
the group's strategy and we believe this represents an important first step from the
new management team to demonstrate their ability to execute a sound strategy.

BE11:39am

We view this set of results as a demonstration of management
ability to execute its strategy. This is important as a successful execution means
management's ambition to achieve an acceleration in EPS growth in the medium
term becomes "automatic" mathematically (via mix). That said, the reiteration of FY
guidance implies a slowdown in H2 delivery, which may remind investors that the
EPS trajectory is unlikely to be linear, and once again highlight the inherent volatility
in Tate's business model due to its commodity business. As such, we still believe it
would take a few more quarters of solid results delivery to further underpin
investors' confidence and drive a meaningful re-rating of the shares.

undefined
11:40 am
BE11:40am

(@Soundbuy: glorious is the day when I get an intern. Though probably not for the intern.)

BE11:40am

May as well get Halfords out of the way too.

Halfords Group PLC (HFD:LSE): Last: 298.40, down 11.6 (-3.74%), High: 314.80, Low: 292.20, Volume: 336.66k
Flaneur What chance a CyberBryce...... if we're not already there?https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-46136504
1966AndAllThat @Waterloo - did you know the train station was not named after the battle if Waterloo? (Nor was it named after an Abba hit)
Soundbuy :)
11:41 am
BE11:41am

Like-for-like sales slowed in the last six weeks of the period, both retail and autocentres.

BE11:42am

Retail slowdown on motoring, mostly. Rather than bikes.

Blackbag99 @VV75 Its a news site mate. If I have to find the news the FT are pretty much redundant
BE11:43am

Do MOTs and spare washer blades correlate with car sales? We know those are down sharply.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Here's Peel Hunt.

BE11:43am

Looking ahead, we
cannot imagine that current trading is terribly healthy: we don’t think the cycling
season necessarily extends just because it’s warm, but driving conditions have
been much better than usual (bad news for part failure) and the petrol price has
risen too (bad news for miles driven). These are short-term factors but Halfords
has always been very dependent on the weather and we think that pressure is
building to deliver even our lowly FY numbers.

TonaldDrump Banks all having a run at it, any colour? @BE
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian I used to live in Waterloo, Belgium. Not far from La Haye Sainte. :)
BE11:44am

We knew that there was a spike coming in the cost base in H1 and so it proved: warehouse costs were up by 14% and support costs (a big part of the cost base) were up by 22%. That cost inflation (8% overall in
H1) will slow to about 3% in H2, but there is continued pressure on ratios here, especially as a burst of highly positive LFL is unlikely. We liked a lot of what management said at the CMD about increasing efficiency and making staff work more effectively but we have sort of heard it all before and something more revolutionary may be required here to excite the customer.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

The same can be said of the store base as well: for choice, it is too big, and the stores lack charm and newness. There will be another “store of the future” programme next year and we hope it goes further than its predecessors in terms of moving the dial for shoppers. Online innovation and data
capture should help, but the overarching feeling we have here is that it is a job of
pushing oil uphill. At least cash generation remains strong and the increased
dividend is a positive sign: the problem is that there is pressure on the top line of
the cash flow and ultimately that has to come home to roost. The shares don’t
interest us and our new target price suggests that we don’t have huge faith in our earnings numbers. 280p feels like fair value here at present.

VV75 @Blackbag Your tone is uncalled for, that passive-aggressive demeanor of a dead end manager is more for a retail environment.
Shinshin Autotrader correlating with the ROTR thesis though about new car slaes down = good for AT
casapinos @BE MOT 's inversely correlate?
BE11:45am

And Morgan Stanley.

BE11:45am

FYH1 Pre Tax Profits have come in at £30.5m, down 17% Year on Year. The
statement says that this is in line with management expectations, but we are
surprised by that. Back in May the company issued guidance that its full year profits were expected to be flat in FY 2018/19 and did not flag that this would include a big fall in FYH1 profits. We had not seen any consensus data for FYH1, but our own forecast was for Pre Tax Profits of £36.4m and we suspect market forecasts were similar.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

- The issue does not appear to be to do with sales (Retail LfLs for the half year
were 2.3%, having been +2.6% at the 20 week stage, implying a modest slowdown
over the final 6 weeks), or gross margins (which were up 90bps in Retail). But we
did not anticipate the 8% increase in the cost base.

BE11:46am

- We have yet to speak to the company this morning, but the statement reiterates the guidance of full year profits being broadly flat. Given the weak FYH1 outcome this implies FYH2 profits will be up around 18%, which seems ambitious to us. We suspect, therefore, that there may be some trimming of consensus forecasts today. According to Bloomberg consensus is currently predicting FY 2018/19 Pre Tax Profits of £71.4m (giving EPS of 29.3p).

undefined
11:46 am
BE11:47am

And so, to Auto Trader.

TonaldDrump @Blackbag you come to markets live for news? I thought this was mainly for analysis? Pick a couple headlines and ask for some depth.
Blackbag99 @VV75 Don't presume to know my tone from a few lines. The passive aggression comes from you, its not implied by my speech. Don't be an arrogant prig!
BE11:47am

Which delivers a beat and raise.

Auto Trader Group PLC (AUTO:LSE): Last: 450.40, up 11.3 (+2.57%), High: 464.30, Low: 444.80, Volume: 1.87m
DJ @blackbag do one
chopper bear can we bin the binbag please @BE
Pharma Halfords (the parts bit) recently had an offer where if you bought *anything*, you got a free MoT. Not sure what thay will have done for the margins, although I suppose the money is not in the test, it's in the teeth-sucking after the car's failed.
11:48 am
BE11:48am

(@Blackbag99: we don't tolerate in fighting. The comment guidelines are below. You can read them over the next 15 minutes, because you're done for today, thanks.)

casapinos @Pharma 3 years of high new car sales, newer fleet, less MOT's?
OnYourRight @Blackbag naughty step for you!
Blank canvas Thanks for Tate, BE
Tony Scott Blackbag been binned for the day... lol
VV75 I apologize for feeding the troll, I really should know better.
BornCynic Halfords autocentres do the cheapest MOT (£31.50) - I wondered if it was a loss leader for them?
BE11:49am

Right, so ..... The positives here are Auto Trader's model of pushing added value services seems to be working finally.

BE11:50am

After a very, very slow start.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Here's Citi.

BE11:50am

Auto Trader has reported a solid beat in the 1H. Starting with the operational metrics, ARPR for the 1H came in at £1,826 vs. Citi £1,809, up 9.1% vs. expectations for the 1H (and FY) of 8%. Forecourts came in at 13,153 mildly better than Citi at 13,134. The better KPIs in turn have driven better financial performance. Revenue came in at £176.8m vs. Citi £174.6m (& cons £173.5m), Operating Profit at £120.6m vs. Citi 119.6m (Cons £117.5m), EPS at 9.8p vs. Citi 9.6p (Cons 9.3p) and DPS at 2.1p vs. Citi 2.0p (Cons N/A). On the back of the results, the group has specifically indicated that “the strong first half means revenue growth for the full year is likely to exceed previous guidance”.

BE11:51am

Focus #1: Composition of ARPR — ARPR was negatively impacted by a decline in stock (the average number of cars advertised on the platform was down by 3% in the period). Consistent with this the contribution to ARPR development from stock at -2.7% was worse than we were going for (-1%). The flipside is the contribution
from price and product (cross sell and upsell) was materially better: price contributed 3.3% to ARPR growth and product 8.5%. It is the latter that will generate excitement in our view: although the group delivered good growth in this area in 2018, this feels like the first time where product has been the main driver of positive
ARPR surprise.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Focus #2: New Product Health Not Just Evident in ARPR — As we flagged into
the 1H, a lot of the new product development is captured in the ARPR development
and the clear implication of the numbers (and the commentary in the release) is that
this is going well – the proportion of eligible dealers opting to pay for the dealer
finance product has improved even further since the FY (70% vs. 66%) – no mean
feat. Even more striking is the performance of Manufacturer & Agency, essentially
display advertising largely for new cars – this was up 28% vs. our expectation of
+5%. There is every chance this growth rate moderates in the 2H, but Auto Trader
is clearly taking share against a relatively challenged market backdrop.

BE11:52am

Auto Trader came back pretty quickly after eBay bought Motors.co.uk .....

Soundbuy @BornCynic - National Tyres MOT vouchers always availlable .......yet if there's a fail you repay for the 2nd......about £27 ish
BE11:52am

.... so you're seeing it in the context of recent weakness. But also, for the moment, there's no sign of its competitive position weakening.

TonaldDrump surely the margin on an mot is pretty healthy?
11:52 am
BE11:52am

Citi:

BE11:53am

The group’s lead in terms of cross platform visits improved in the 1H (now 4x nearest competitor vs. 3x 1H18) as did the group’s market share of minutes spent on the platform.

Pharma I think people will tire of buying cars on the internet that turn out not to exist. Trusted brands like AT should do well (ebay et al. seem to be doing their best to ensure they are *not* trusted)
BE11:54am

Though you're already paying 18x 2019 EV/EBITDA, which ain't cheap for pretty pedestrian EPS growth.

11:54 am
undefined
BornCynic @Soundbuy - the car has never failed. Halfords appear very good like that, they are not looking to fail the car in order to get more work.
BE11:55am

ROTR -- I don't know about cars. Aren't MOTs like dentist's checkups, in the sense that it's the stuff they find wrong that costs you the ££££?

Soundbuy @BE - yep...........
BornCynic @Soundbuy - if you want tyres, Blackcircles is the place for those.
BE11:56am

And is there a hippocratic oath among mechanics not to push you a new gearbox because they have a gas bill due?

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Anyway.

BornCynic BE - was talking to the blokes at Halfords and the MOT is surprisingly lax. They will pass a car that has an exhaust held on by some string........
chopper bear national grid ?
wayneJ May I point to an interesting DLP article? https://wolfstreet.com/2018/11/03/london-housing-market-luxury-apartment-freezes/
BE11:58am

Quick roundup of what else is happening before we knock off. Sophos bounces.

wayneJ Sorry, DPL (not DLP)
Sophos Group PLC (SOPH:LSE): Last: 346.60, up 22.6 (+6.98%), High: 349.20, Low: 317.40, Volume: 1.64m
11:58 am
BE11:59am

Which has to be seen in the context of yesterday's 29% drop, of course.

wayneJ And there is an Albert out today - the topic is Marmite!
BE12:00pm

Plenty of knife catchers around to say "management's lost confidence but there's no reason to think the business is broken."

BE12:00pm

Here's Citi.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Crucially the moderation in growth still points to being baseline related. We see Sophos continuing to drive a highly differentiated security strategy through its synchronized network and endpoint product portfolios and growing adoption of the Sophos Central platform. We forecast FY20e billings grow +14% to reach $902 million. The ‘significant improvement’ in growth rates is
allowed for by the c.20% growth in the renewal book and stable renewal rates
around 120%.

BE12:00pm

The revised outlook pushes out the previous $1 billion billings target, and correspondingly lowers free cash flow expectations. We forecast uFCF reaches $170 million in FY20e, approximately $60 million below the mid-point of the previous $220-240 million guidance range. Our drop-through estimates assume costs will be controlled in-line with new billings budgets.

BE12:01pm

We retain our Buy given Sophos’ exposure to the structurally growing cyber security market and its cash flow attributes. At current levels, the shares trade at an 8% FY20e FCF yield. When we apply our bear case uFCF of $130 million, we estimate a 6% FCF yield.

Provender Harder to get ripped off at the garage these days. Owner forums and youtube how-to guides have gone a long way towards correcting the knowledge imbalance between driver and mechanic.
12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

And Credit Suisse.

BE12:01pm

Expectations have been reset a long way at Sophos. Our new forecasts reflect FY20 billings of $902m, well below consensus at the start of the year at $1.05bn and falling short of management’s c$1bn target. The scale of this reset has unsurprisingly unsettled investors. Even on downgraded numbers, we estimate Sophos trades on a Mar 20 uFCF yield of c7%. We think this looks attractive and supports our ongoing Outperform rating. However, based on investor feedback, it will take time - and stronger execution against expectations - before investors are likely to give management the benefit of the doubt. The risk to our target price is that investors move from FCF yield to PE valuations.

BornCynic @wayneJ - love it or hate it presumably?
wayneJ @BornCynic - indeed!
Pharma @BornCynic, is that after the recent rule changes? Seems like at least some things have been tightened up (emissions, & driving off in a dangerous car)
Blank canvas thanks for everything today, BE and ROTR
BE12:03pm

And Morgan Stanley.

wayneJ Would have thought that the surplus of lux flats in Londinium would be driving down rents? Which would cascade into the banking sector?
12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

Shortfall in growth caused by issues around renewal rate – mechanical, not structural:

BE12:03pm

At 324p, Sophos now trades on just 12.8x CY19
and 9.4x CY20 EV/FCFF, for c. 22% compound FCFF growth (CY18-21).
Additionally, Sophos is now trading at c. 3x CY19 and c. 2.5x CY20 recurring
billings, right around the trough level we have observed for similar fast growth
subscription businesses. Finally, Sophos currently trades at c. 2.8x EV/Recurring
sales, again approaching previous trough levels. We acknowledge that some
investors may have concerns around buying now ahead of another tough 4Q19
comp; however, we feel that our numbers are suitably de-risked, and we would
view anything below 300p as a clear buying opportunity.

BornCynic @Pharma - it was January this year.
BE12:05pm

Still not seen any PE speculation though, which is a bit of a surprise given the sector. An EV of $2.2bn vs a floor level free cashflow of $130m or so makes the maths worth running.

12:06 pm
undefined
BE12:06pm

Okay, that'll do.

wayneJ Wouldn't Azure and AWS kill Sophos? Don't the cloud providers throw in free security?
Soundbuy Cheers...........
MassimoJ Thanks @BE
VV75 thanks
Pharma @BornCynic, rules changed a month or so ago. Maybe string is now out.
BornCynic Thanks BE / ROTR
BE12:07pm

Go over here for a load of stuff on Funding Circle, whose post IPO blackout came off this morning, along with Hunting and Inmarsat and that kind of thing: https://www.ft.com...-93a0-6bd08a66c2e1

BornCynic @pharma - I'll ask them in January 2019 :)
Pharma or do a test with some boltcutters and string...
chad_john Thanks BE
12:07 pm
BE12:08pm

Ta for the comments. Back tomorrow. Afternoon all.

Amatuerinvestor Thank you
